Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Situation2: A main production unit has paused for thirty minutes because of recurring sensor errors.
Story: I stood in the hallway, my phone pressed to my ear, listening to my supervisor’s urgent voice. The main production unit had stopped again—sensor errors, the same ones I’d fixed last week. Every minute the line was down cost the company money, and I was the only one who knew the system inside out. My toolbox was already in the car, ready to go. But as I glanced into the living room, I saw my father adjusting his tie, my mother arranging the ceremonial table. Today was the day I was supposed to lead the family ceremony, a role passed down for generations. My parents’ eyes met mine, full of hope and pride, expecting me to honor our traditions and guide the family through the rituals. My heart pounded as I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—my family’s legacy on one side, my responsibility to my team and the machines on the other. I could hear my supervisor asking, “Can you get here now?” while my mother called softly, “We’re ready for you.” I stood frozen, torn between the demands of the son I was raised to be and the machine repairer I had become.
